H0.text: Populations living in an area are what a biological community is made up of.

H1.text: Natural resources present in an area make up a biological community.

H2.text: Members of a species on Earth are what a biological community is made up of.

H3.text: Environments on Earth make up a biological community.

A4.text: An ecosystem, originally defined by Tansley (1935), is a biotic community (or biocenosis) along with its physical environment (or biotope).

A5.text: A biocenosis (UK English, biocoenosis, also biocenose, biocoenose, biotic community, biological community, ecological community, life assemblage), coined by Karl MÃ¶bius in 1877, describes the interacting organisms living together in a habitat (biotope).

A6.text: Ecology studies populations of different species rather than populations of a single species.

A7.text: Each community consists of populations of animals and plants that live together, interacting and being dependent on each other.
